By starting from geometrical considerations, show that, if Cartesian coordinates are transformed in accordance with the formulae x=ap*cos(phi), y=bp*sin(phi) (a and b are constants), the elementary area becomes d(sigma) = abp dp d(phi).
Answers: The given transformation can be regarded as the result of two transformations: (1) x'=p*cos(phi), y'=p*sin(phi), and (2) x=ax', y=by'. The first is a transformation from Cartesian to polar coordinates (the elementary area of which is p*dp*d(phi)); the second represents a simple expansion along the coordinate axes. A rectangle with sides dx' and dy' is transformed into a rectangle with sides dx = a dx' and dy = b dy'. Hence d(sigma) = dx*dy = ab*dx'*dy' = abp*dp*d(phi).

In problems 3675-3680, find the moments of inertia of the homogeneous bodies with mass equal to M. The rectangular parallelepiped with ribs a, b and c with respect to each of the ribs and with respect to the centre of gravity.
A sphere with respect to a tangent line.
The ellipsoid x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 + z^2/c^2 = 1 with respect to each of its three axes.
The right circular cylinder (base radius R, height H) with respect to a base diameter and with respect to a diameter of its central section.
The hollow sphere of external radius R, internal radius r, with respect to a diameter.
The paraboloid of revolution (base radius R, height H) with respect to the axis through its centre of gravity and perpendicular to the axis of revolution (equatorial moment).

The lateral surface of the frustrum of a cone (base radii R and r, height H) with respect to its axis.

Find the mass of a square lamina of side 2a, if the density of the material of the lamina is proportional to the square of the distance from the point of intersection of the diagonals and is equal to unity at the corners.

A plane annular ring is bounded by two concentric circles of radii R and r (R > r). Find the mass of the ring, given that the density is inversely proportional to the distance from its centre. The density on the inner circumference is equal to unity.

Mass is distributed over the area bounded by an ellipse with semi-axes a and b in such a way that its density is proportional to the distance from the major axis, the density at unit distance from this axis being gamma. Find the total mass.

A body is bounded by two concentric spherical surfaces, the radii of which are r and R (R > r). Knowing that the density of the material is inversely proportional to the distance from the centre of the sphere and is equal to gamma at unit distance, find the total mass of the body.

Find the mass of the body bounded by a right circular cylinder of radius R and height H, if the density at any point is numerically equal to the square of the distance of the point from the centre of the cylinder base.

Find the mass of a body bounded by a circular cone, the height of which is equal to h, and the angle between the axis and generator of which is equal to alpha; the density is proportional to the nth power of the distance from the plane through the vertex of the cone parallel to the base, the density at unit distance being gamma (n > 0).
Answers: pi*gamma*h^(n+2)*tan^2(alpha) / (n+3). If the axis of the cone is taken as Oz, and its vertex as the origin, the equation of the cone becomes x^2+y^2-z^2*tan^2(alpha)=0.

Questions: Find the mass of a sphere of radius R, if the density is proportional to the cube of the distance from the centre and is equal to gamma at unit distance.

Find the mass of a body bounded by the paraboloid x^2+y^2=2az and the sphere x^2+y^2+z^2=3a^2 (z>0), if the density at any given point is equal to the square of the sum of the coordinates of the point.
The density at any point of the sphere x^2+y^2+z^2<=2Rz is numerically equal to the square of the distance of the point from the origin. Find the coordinates of the centre of gravity of the sphere.
Answers: xi=0, eta=0, zeta=5/4 * R. Transform to cylindrical coordinates.

Questions: Find the statical moment of the common part of the spheres x^2+y^2+z^2<=R^2 and x^2+y^2+z^2<=2Rz with respect to the xOy plane. The density at any point of the body is numerically equal to the distance of the point from the xOy plane.
Answers: 59/480 * pi * R^5. See hint on previous problem.

Questions: Prove that the moment of inertia of a body with respect to any axis is equal to Md^2+Ic, where M is the mass of the body, d is the distance from the axis to the centre of gravity of the body, and Ic is the moment of inertia with respect to the axis parallel to the given axis and passing through the centre of gravity (Steiner's theorem; cf. problem 3662).
Answers: Choose the system of coordinates so that the origin coincides with the centre of gravity of the body and one of the coordinate axes is parallel to the axis with respect to which the moment of inertia is being sought.

Questions: Given a homogeneous sphere of radius R and density gamma, find the force with which it attracts a material particle of mass m at a distance a from its centre (a>R). Show that the force of interaction is the same as when the total mass of the sphere is concentrated at its centre.
Answers: kM*m/a^2, where M is the mass of the sphere, and k is the gravitational constant.

Questions: Prove that the Newton force of interaction between two homogeneous spheres is the same as when the masses of the spheres are concentrated at their centres.
Answers: Use the result of the previous problem.

Questions: Given the non-homogeneous continuous sphere x^2+y^2+z^2<=R^2 with density varying in accordance with the law gamma = lambda*z^2, find the force with which it attracts a material particle of mass m, located on the z axis at a distance 2R from the centre of the sphere.
Answers: 17/56 km, where k is the gravitational constant.

Questions: Given a homogeneous body bounded by two concentric spheres (spherical layer), prove that the force of attraction by the layer on a point situated in the interior cavity is equal to zero.
Answers: The result follows from the formula for the force of attraction of a homogeneous sphere on a point.

Questions: Find the centre of pressure of a rectangle with sides a and b (a > b), a greater side of which is located along the free surface of the fluid, whilst the plane of the rectangle is perpendicular to this surface. Show that the position of the centre of pressure does not vary if the plane of the rectangle is inclined at an angle alpha != 0 to the surface of the fluid. How are the above results affected if the greater side a is at a depth h (remaining parallel to the surface) instead of lying on the surface?
Answers: The centre of pressure lies on the axis of symmetry of the rectangle perpendicular to side a, at a distance 2/3 b from the side lying on the surface. In the second case (side a situated at a depth h) the distance of the centre of pressure from the upper side will be b/2 * (2b+3h)/(3b+2h), where l = h/sin(alpha). (With l >> b the centre of pressure almost coincides with the centre of the rectangle).

Questions:
A triangle of height h is in a plane inclined at an angle alpha to the free surface of a fluid. What is the depth of the centre of pressure of the triangle, if:
(a) its base lies on the fluid surface?
(b) its vertex lies on the surface, whilst its base is parallel to the surface?

Find the centre of pressure of the figure bounded by an ellipse with semi-axes a and b (a > b), given that the major axis is perpendicular to the fluid surface and the upper end of this axis lies at a distance h from the surface.
Answers: The centre of pressure lies on the major axis of the ellipse, at a distance a + a^2/(4(a+h)) from its upper end.

Questions: Prove that the fluid pressure on a plane area, arbitrarily submerged in fluid, is equal to the weight of a cylindrical column of the fluid, situated above the area, when the area lies horizontally at the depth of its centre of pressure.
Answers: Choose the system of coordinates so that one of the coordinate planes coincides with the plane of the lamina and one of the axes coincides with the line of intersection of the fluid surface and the plane of the lamina.

Evaluate or establish the divergence of the improper integrals of problems 3703-3711: integral from 0 to inf dx integral from 2x to inf xe^(-y) sin(y)/y^2 dy.
Answers: 1/16. See the hint on the previous problem.

Questions: Discover which of the improper integrals of problems 3712-3715 over the circular domain of radius R with centre at the origin is convergent: integral_D ln(sqrt(x^2+y^2)) dx dy (see Course, sec. 179).
Discover which of the improper integrals of problems 3712-3715 over the circular domain of radius R with centre at the origin is convergent: integral_D e^(-x^2-y^2) / (x^2+y^2) dx dy.
Discover which of the improper integrals of problems 3712-3715 over the circular domain of radius R with centre at the origin is convergent: integral_D sin(x^2+y^2) / sqrt((x^2+y^2)^3) dx dy.
Discover which of the improper integrals of problems 3712-3715 over the circular domain of radius R with centre at the origin is convergent: integral_D cos(x^2+y^2) / (x^2+y^2) dx dy.
Can a number m be chosen such that the improper integral integral_D dx dy / (sqrt(x^2+y^2))^m, taken over the whole of the plane, is convergent?
Evaluate the improper integrals of problems 3717-3719: integral from 0 to inf integral from 0 to inf integral from 0 to inf dx dy dz / sqrt((1+x+y+z)^7).
Evaluate the improper integrals of problems 3717-3719: integral from 0 to inf integral from 0 to inf integral from 0 to inf xy dx dy dz / (1+x^2+y^2+z^2)^3.
Evaluate the improper integrals of problems 3717-3719: integral from -inf to inf integral from -inf to inf integral from -inf to inf e^(-x^2-y^2-z^2) dx dy dz.
Answers: π*sqrt(π); use Poisson's integral integral_0^inf e^(-x^2) dx = sqrt(pi)/2.

Questions: Examine the convergence of the improper integrals of problems 3720-3722, taken over the sphere Omega of radius R with centre at the origin: integral_Omega dx dy dz / (sqrt(x^2+y^2+z^2))^3 * ln(sqrt(x^2+y^2+z^2)).

Examine the convergence of the improper integrals of problems 3720-3722, taken over the sphere Omega of radius R with centre at the origin: integral_Omega ln(sqrt(x^2+y^2+z^2)) / (x^2+y^2+z^2) dx dy dz.

Find the volume of the body bounded by the surface z = (x^2+y^2)e^(-(x^2+y^2)) and the plane z = 0.
Evaluate the volume of the body bounded by the surface z = x^2y^2e^(-(x^2+y^2)) and the plane z = 0.
Find the volume of the body bounded by the plane z=0 and the part of the surface z=xe^(-(x^2+y^2)) lying above this plane.
Given a homogeneous body bounded by the right circular cylinder of base radius R (height H, density gamma), find the force acting on a particle of mass m situated at the centre of the base.
Answers: 2πkmγ(R+H−√(R^2+H^2)). The force is directed along the axis of the cylinder.

Questions: Given a homogeneous body bounded by the right circular cone of base radius R and height H (density gamma), find the force with which the body attracts a particle of mass m located at the vertex of the cone.
Answers: 2πkmγH/l * (l-H), where l is the generator of the cone. The force is directed along the axis of the cone.

Questions:
Given a non-homogeneous continuous sphere of radius R, the density gamma of which is connected with the distance from the centre r by the relationship gamma = a - br (a > 0, b > 0):

Using the equation integral from 0 to b dx/(1+ax) = 1/a * ln(1+ab), obtain by differentiation with respect to the parameter the formula: integral from 0 to b x dx / (1+ax)^2 = 1/a^2 * ln(1+ab) - b/(a(1+ab)).
Starting from the equation integral from 0 to inf dx/(x^2+a^2) = 1/a * arc tan(x/a), evaluate integral from 0 to inf dx/(x^2+a^2)^3.
Starting from the equation integral from 0 to inf dx/(x^2+a^2) = pi/(2a), evaluate integral from 0 to inf dx/(x^2+a^2)^n (n is a positive integer).
Evaluate the integral integral from 0 to inf e^(-ax)*x^(n-1) dx (n is a positive integer) with a > 0, by finding as a preliminary integral from 0 to inf e^(-ax) dx.
By starting from the equation (see problem 2318): integral from 0 to pi/2 dx/(a^2*cos^2(x)+b^2*sin^2(x)) = pi/(2|ab|), find integral from 0 to pi/2 dx/(a^2*cos^2(x)+b^2*sin^2(x))^2.
Answers: π(a^2+b^2)/(4|ab|^3). Differentiate with respect to a and b and add the results.

Questions: Evaluate the integrals of problems 3737-3749 with the aid of differentiation with respect to a parameter: integral from 0 to inf (1-e^(-ax))/x * e^(-x) dx (a > -1).
integral from 0 to inf (1-e^(-ax^2))/(x*e^(x^2)) dx (a > -1).
integral from 0 to 1 (arc tan ax)/x * dx / sqrt(1-x^2).
integral from 0 to 1 (ln(1-a^2x^2))/(x^2*sqrt(1-x^2)) dx (a^2 < 1).
integral from 0 to inf (arc tan ax)/(x(1+x^2)) dx.
Answers: pi/2 * ln(1+a), if a>=0; -pi/2 * ln(1-a) if a<=0.

Questions: integral from 0 to 1 (ln(1-a^2x^2))/sqrt(1-x^2) dx (a^2 < 1).
integral from 0 to pi (ln(1+a cos x))/cos x dx (a^2 < 1).

integral from 0 to inf e^(-ax) * (sin bx - sin cx)/x dx (a > 0).
integral from 0 to inf e^(-ax) * (cos bx - cos cx)/x dx (a > 0).
integral from 0 to pi/2 ln(a^2*cos^2(x) + b^2*sin^2(x)) dx.
Answers: pi*ln((a+b)/2). Differentiate with respect to a or with respect to b.

Questions: Having evaluated integral from 0 to pi/2 (arctan(a*tan(x)))/tan(x) dx, find integral from 0 to pi/2 x/tan(x) dx.
Answers: pi/2 * ln(1+a) if a>0; -pi/2 * ln(1-a) if a<0;

Questions: By using the equation integral from 0 to 1 x^n dx = 1/(n+1), evaluate integral from 0 to 1 (x^beta - x^alpha)/ln(x) dx (alpha > -1, beta > -1).

By starting from the relationship integral from 0 to inf e^(-z^2) dz = sqrt(pi)/2 (Poisson's integral), deduce the equation 1/sqrt(x) = 2/sqrt(pi) * integral from 0 to inf e^(-zx) dz (x>0), and use this to evaluate the integrals (Fresnel or diffraction integrals): 
(a) integral from 0 to inf cos(x)/sqrt(x) dx; (b) integral from 0 to inf sin(x)/sqrt(x) dx

Let f(x) be continuous for x>=0 and tend to a finite limit f(inf) as x->inf. Further, let integral_0^inf f'(ax) dx be uniformly convergent for 0 < a <= a <= b. Prove that, with these conditions, integral_0^inf (f(ax)-f(bx))/x dx = [f(inf)-f(0)]ln(a/b).
Answers: The result is obtained by integrating f'(x) with respect to x from 0 to inf, then integrating the result with respect to a from b to a.

Questions: Evaluate the integrals of problems 3755-3756 by using the results of problem 3754: integral from 0 to inf (arctan(ax) - arctan(bx))/x dx.
Evaluate the integrals of problems 3755-3756 by using the results of problem 3754: integral from 0 to inf (e^(-ax^n) - e^(-bx^n))/x dx (n>0).

Let f(x) be continuous for x>=0 and let integral_A^inf f(x)/x dx be convergent for any A>0. Prove that, with these conditions, if a>0 and b>0, we have integral_0^inf (f(ax)-f(bx))/x dx = f(0)ln(b/a) (cf. problem 3754).
Answers: I = lim [integral_eps_a^A (f(ax)/x)dx - integral_eps_b^A (f(bx)/x)dx] = lim [integral_eps*a^A*a (f(z)/z)dz - integral_eps*b^A*b (f(z)/z)dz] = lim [integral_eps*a^eps*b (f(z)/z)dz - integral_A*a^A*b (f(z)/z)dz]. The second integral tends to 0 as A->inf. By the mean value theorem, the first integral is f(xi)*ln(b/a).

Evaluate the integrals of problems 3758-3762 by using the result of problem 3757 (a > 0, b > 0): integral from 0 to inf (sin^2(x))/x^2 dx.

The Laplace function Phi(x) is defined thus: Phi(x) = 2/sqrt(pi) * integral from 0 to x e^(-t^2) dt (this function plays a large part in the theory of probability). Prove the relationships: (1) integral from 0 to inf Phi(az) dz = (e^(-a^2x^2)-1)/(a*sqrt(pi)) + x*Phi(ax); (2) integral from 0 to inf [1 - Phi(x)] dz = 1/sqrt(pi).
Answers: (1) Integrate by parts. (2) See hint on problem 3763.

Questions: Functions si(x) and ci(x) are usually defined thus: si(x) = - integral from x to inf sin(t)/t dt ("integral sine") and ci(x) = - integral from x to inf cos(t)/t dt ("integral cosine"). Prove that integral from 0 to inf sin(x)si(x) dx = integral from 0 to inf cos(x)ci(x) dx = -pi/4.
Answers: Use the second method of solution of problem 3763. When proving the second relationship it is necessary to investigate the integral integral from 0 to inf sin(ax)cos(x*sin(theta))/x dx with |a|>1 and |a|<=1. This is done by transforming the expression in the numerator, and recalling that integral_0^inf sin(x)/x dx = pi/2 (Dirichlet's integral).

Questions: The function J_0(x), defined as J_0(x) = 2/pi * integral from 0 to pi/2 cos(x sin theta) d(theta), is termed the Bessel function of zero order. Prove that: (1) integral from 0 to inf e^(-ax) J_0(x) dx = 1/sqrt(1+a^2) (a>0); (2) integral from 0 to inf sin(ax)/x J_0(x) dx = {pi/2, if a>=1; arcsin a, if |a|<=1; -pi/2, if a<=-1}.
Answers: Substitute in the left-hand side of the required equation the expressions for y' and y'' obtained by differentiation of the integral y with respect to the parameter. One of the terms obtained must be integrated by parts.

Questions: Prove that the function y = integral from 0 to inf e^(-xz^2)/(1+z^2) dz satisfies the differential equation y''+y=1/x.

integral_L sqrt(2y) ds, where L is the first arc of the cycloid x=a(t-sin(t)), y=a(1-cos(t)).
Obtain a formula for evaluating integral_L F(x,y) ds, if curve L is given by the equation rho=rho(phi) (phi1 <= phi <= phi2) in polar coordinates.
Answers: integral from phi1 to phi2 F(rho*cos(phi), rho*sin(phi)) * sqrt(rho^2 + rho'^2) d(phi).

Questions: Evaluate integral_L (x-y) ds, where L is the circle x^2+y^2=ax.

A current I flows along a circuit in the form of a square of side a. What is the force exerted by the current on a magnetic dipole m at the centre of the square?

Prove that the current I flowing along the arc of a curve whose equation is given in polar coordinates by rho = rho(phi), exerts a force f = ml * integral from phi1 to phi2 d(phi)/rho on a magnetic dipole situated at the pole.
Answers: Hint: Use the formula for the angle between the tangent and the radius vector.

Questions: What is the force exerted by a current I flowing in a closed elliptic circuit on a magnetic dipole m situated at a focus of the ellipse?
Answers: 2πml/b^2, where a and b are the semi-axes of the ellipse.

Questions: What is the force exerted by the current I flowing in an infinite parabolic circuit on a magnetic dipole m located at the focus of the parabola? The distance from the vertex to the focus is equal to p/2.

What is the force exerted by a current I flowing in a circular circuit of radius R on a magnetic dipole m located at a point P, lying on the perpendicular to the plane of the circle through its centre and distant h from the centre? Given a fixed h, for what value of R is this force a maximum?
Answers: The force is 2πmIR^2 / (h^2+R^2)^(3/2). The force is a maximum for R=h*sqrt(2).

Questions: Evaluate the line integrals of problems 3806-3821: integral_L x dy, where L is the triangle formed by the coordinate axes and the straight line x/2+y/3=1, taken in a positive direction (i.e. anticlockwise).
integral_L x dy, where L is the segment of the straight line x/a+y/b=1 from its point of intersection with the axis of abscissae to its point of intersection with the axis of ordinates.
integral_L (x^2-y^2) dx, where L is the arc of the parabola y=x^2 from the point (0,0) to the point (2,4).
integral_L (x^2+y^2) dy, where L is the rectangle with corners (given in order of the circuit round them) at A(0,0), B(2,0), C(4,4) and D(0,4).
integral from (0,0) to (pi, 2pi) (-x cos y dx + y sin x dy) along the segment joining the points (0,0) and (pi, 2pi).
integral from (0,0) to (1,1) xy dx + (y-x) dy along the curves (1) y=x, (2) y=x^2, (3) y^2=x, (4) y=x^3.
integral from (0,0) to (1,1) 2xy dx + x^2 dy along the curve (1) y=x, (2) y=x^2, (3) y=x^3, (4) y^2=x.
Answers: The integral is equal to 1 in all four cases.

integral_L y dx - x dy, where L is the ellipse x=a cos t, y=b sin t, taken in the positive direction.
integral_L (y^2 dx - x^2 dy) / (x^2+y^2), where L is the semi-circle x=a cos t, y=a sin t from t1=0 to t2=pi.
integral_L (2a-y) dx - (a-y) dy, where L is the first (from the origin) arc of the cycloid x=a(t-sin t), y=a(1-cos t).
integral_L (x^2 dy - y^2 dx) / (x^(5/3)+y^(5/3)), where L is the quadrant of the astroid x=R cos^3(t), y=R sin^3(t), from the point (R,0) to the point (0,R).
integral_L x dx + y dy + (x+y-1) dz, where L is the segment of a straight line from the point (1,1,1) to the point (2,3,4).

A force has a magnitude inversely proportional to the distance of its point of application from the xOy plane, whilst it is directed towards the origin. Find the work done when a particle of mass m moves under the action of the force along the straight line x=at, y=bt, z=ct from the point M(a,b,c) to the point N(2a,2b,2c).
Answers: k/c * sqrt(a^2+b^2+c^2) * ln(2), where k is a coefficient of proportionality.

Answers: 0.5k ln 2, where k is a coefficient of proportionality.

Answers: Hint: Differentiate the given relationship, which yields the equation v^2 = (C/m) * (s/t).

Assuming that the resistance of the water to the boat is proportional to its speed, find the speed 2 min after stopping the motor; find also the distance travelled by the boat during 1 min after stopping the motor.

The bottom of a cylindrical vessel with a cross-section S cm^2 and a vertical axis contains a small circular hole of area q cm^2, which can be closed by a diaphragm (as in a camera lens). Fluid is poured into the vessel to a height h. The diaphragm starts to open at time t = 0, the area of the opening being proportional to time and the aperture being completely open after T sec. The rate of cooling of a body is proportional to the difference in temperature between the body and the environment. We assumed that the coefficient of proportionality is constant in problems 2710-2711. It is assumed in certain calculations to be linearly dependent on time: k = k0(1 + at). On this assumption, find the relationship between the body temperature θ and time t, putting θ = θ0 at t = 0, the temperature of the environment being θ1.

The rate of growth of the area of a young leaf of Queen Victoria, which is well-known to have a circular shape, is proportional to the circumference of the leaf and the amount of sunlight incident on it. The latter is in turn proportional to the area of the leaf and the cosine of the angle between the incident ray and the vertical. Find the relationship between the area S of the leaf and time t, if we know that the area is 1600 cm^2 at 6 a.m. and is 2500 cm^2 at 6 p.m. on the same day. (Assume that the observation is carried out at the equator on the day of the equinox, when the angle between the incident sunlight and the vertical can be taken as 90° at 6 a.m. and at 6 p.m. and 0° at noon.)
Answers: If t is time, measured from midnight and expressed in hours, the differential equation of the problem becomes dS / S*sqrt(S) = k * cos(pi(t-12)/12) dt; whence S = 160000 / [9 - sin(pi(t-12)/12)]^2. The function S(t) is defined for 6 <= t <= 18.
